description: From Middle English commune, comune, from Old French comune, commune, from Medieval Latin commūnia, from Latin commūne (“community, state”), from commūnis (“common”). See also community, communion, common.

entries.meaning: A small community, often rural, whose members share in the ownership of property, and in the division of labour; the members of such a community.
A local political division in many European countries.
(uncountable, obsolete) Communion; sympathetic conversation between friends.
examples: For days of happy commune dead.

entries.meaning: (historical) A self-governing city or league of citizens.

description: From Middle English communen, comunen, from Old French comunier, communier (“to share”), from Latin commūnico. Doublet of communicate.

verbs.description: commune (third-person singular simple present communes, present participle communing, simple past and past participle communed)

entries.meaning: To converse together with sympathy and confidence; to interchange sentiments or feelings; to take counsel.
(intransitive, followed by with) To communicate (with) spiritually; to be together (with); to contemplate or absorb.
examples: He spent a week in the backcountry, communing with nature.
